item.title: Topic 5: Frequentism
item.description: Next, we examine the second main, contemporary approach to scientific reasoning, based in the frequentist understanding of probability. At the heart of its reasoning is the “double negative” inference, based in the “probabilistic modus tollens.” The jargon name for this approach is “null hypothesis significance testing.” We will observe how and why it works, building up from some foundational concepts. Reading Hacking, Chapter 16 “Stability” Hacking, Chapter 17 “Normal Approximations” Hacking, Chapter 18 “Significance and Power” (note on type I/II error) Slides (slide links to come — not live yet)

item.title: Topic 4: Bayesianism
item.description: Bayesianism, as an approach to inductive reasoning, focuses on updating our beliefs in light of new evidence. It is built around a simple formula that expreses a relationship between probabilities. Reading Hacking, Chapter 7 “Bayes' Rule” (pages 69–77) Hacking, Chapter 13 “Personal Probabilities” (pages 151–160) Hacking, Chapter 21 “Learning from Experience as an Evasion of the Problem of Induction” (4 pages) — and if you’re not feeling sufficiently familiar with “the problem of induction,” look at the first pages of Chapter 20 See also John Horgan, “Bayes’s Theorem: What’s the Big Deal?

item.title: Topic 3: Probability
item.description: Here we set up some basic ideas about probability which will be key for understanding the approaches to scientific justification which have dominated the last several decades. Reading Hacking, Introduction to Probability and Inductive Logic Chapter 3 “The Gambler’s Fallacy” This chapter introduces the basic concepts randomness, independence, and probability model but overall it’s pitched to give you a feel for some probability ideas. You might read it more quickly than Chapter 4↓.

item.title: Assignment 1
item.description: Upload your page to “Assignment 1” on Blackboard, under the Assignments area (link in the left sidebar) by, at the latest, (anytime on) Feb 19. Tasks For this exercise, arguments take the form of two or more sentences — with at least three usually making things easier! — the last of which is the conclusion. The phrases in each sentence should fit together. See forallx, Chapter 2 for examples of arguments.

item.title: Topic 2: Early Methods
item.description: As modern science emerged, its practitioners tried to describe how they were reasoning, and how others should reason, to do science. They came to quite different answers! This unit looks quickly at a few landmarks from the period 1600–1900. Reading Francis Bacon, The New Organon (1620). Read Book 2, sections 10–16, starting on page 53 of the linked PDF. Focus on the figuring out the meaning of the beginning and end of the reading, and skim through the content in the middle to get a general sense of what’s going.

item.title: Topic 1: Logic
item.description: Could deductive logic be the logic of science? What is logic? And what is deductive logic? Is non-deductive logic possible? Reading (This is what you should read for this section. The due dates appear on the front page schedule.) forallx Calgary: An Introduction to Formal Logic, Fall 2020 edition, by Magnus et al. Get PDF from here, available in several versions; or, here is a direct link to the the screen-friendly PDF version.

item.title: Interpreting Grades
item.description: This note about grading and interpreting grades just adds some detail to what the course syllabus already says about grading. 4-point scale Grades in this course are assigned and calculated using Hofstra’s 4-point scale (described here in the Hofstra Bulletin). Following the Bulletin, the alphabetical grades, including plus (+) and minus (–), have the following 4-point scale values (and vice versa): letter 4pt Student’s academic performance … A 4.

item.title: Participation Rubric
item.description: This is the participation rubric to be used for grading participation in this course. Read it as saying “A student who demonstrates … earns a grade of X,” where X is the letter grade at the top of the column.1 A B C D F Active role in discussions, drawing on texts Regular, constructive participation drawing on texts Inconsistent constructive participation based on texts Vague comments reflecting limited engagement with texts Persistent lack of engagement with texts Full preparation for approximately every class Substantial preparation, normally Inconsistent evidence of preparation Rare evidence of participation No positive evidence of participation Success at advancing level and depth of discussion, persistently Regular contributions based on assigned material, which sometimes improve discussion and never diminish it Rare or no significant contribution to the level of discussion while not reducing it Activity sometimes diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Activity regularly diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Active engagement with and listening to peers, persistently Sincere efforts to interact with peers, normally Limited engagement with peers Rare interaction with peers No interaction with peers This rubric is significantly based on, and lightly adapted from, one written by another philosophy professor, Jay Odenbaugh.
